content.html:
Welcome back to Aria's garden! Today, Aria and Omar are going to plant some larger vegetables: tomatoes and cucumbers!

You should know the following before going on:

  • How to create, evaluate, and convert between pictures, addition expressions, and multiplication expressions

  • How to define the parts of a multiplication expression

  • How to understand the Commutative Property of Multiplication

  • How to read and interpret a multiplication table

You should also get some paper and a pen or pencil to write with, and find a quiet place to work. Take your time and go through the story at your own pace. Understanding is more important than speed!

Once you’re ready, click Continue to get started!

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not correct. What is the multiplication expression for this box? Use a hint if you need to, and try again!

hint_content.html: The box Omar is pointing to is under the red number 2 and next to the blue number 6. What multiplication expression can be solved to get the number in this box?
Because this box is in the red 2 column and the blue 6 row, the first factor is 2 and the second factor is 6. Write and solve this multiplication expression to find the number in the box.
The multiplication expression is 2 * 6. Use the Commutative Property of Multiplication, an addition expression or a picture to help you evaluate this.

content.html:
“Great!” replied Omar. “The 6th multiple of 2 is 12!"

"Now, what number goes in this box which I am pointing to?"

feedback.html: That's right!
No, that's not right. Remember, to calculate the area of a rectangle, we need to multiply the length by the width. To understand this better, look at this rectangle divided into square centimeters!

content.html:
"Last one," Omar said. "how many square centimeters is the area of this rectangle?"

(Don't include units in your answer. Just write the number!)

feedback.html: Good job!

No, that's not correct. Make sure your first box has the answer to 8 * 1, your last box has the answer to 8 * 9, and you only have one number in each box (you are pressing "add item" after each number you enter.)

hint_content.html:
In each text box, you should only enter one number.

The first text box should have the answer to 8 * 1. The second text box should have the answer to 8 * 2. The last text box should have the answer to 8 * 9.

content.html:
"Way to go!" said Omar. "You got this! Time to enter the multiples of 8 into our table."

"To fill in the eighth row of the multiplication table, write the multiples from 8 * 6 to 8 * 9 in order. Separate them with commas. Don't include any spaces! (Ex. a,b,c,d,e)"

feedback.html: Good job!

No, that's not correct. Make sure your first box has the answer to 9 * 1, your last box has the answer to 9 * 9, and you only have one number in each box (you are pressing "add item" after each number you enter.)

hint_content.html:
In each text box, you should only enter one number.

The first text box should have the answer to 9 * 1. The second text box should have the answer to 9 * 2. The last text box should have the answer to 9 * 9.

content.html:
"Just one more!" said Omar. "Let's finish our table with the multiples of 9!"

"To fill in the ninth row of the multiplication table, write the multiples from 9 * 6 to 9 * 9 in order. Separate them with commas. Don't include any spaces! (Ex. a,b,c,d,e)"

In the last chapter, Aria memorized her multiples, learned about multiplication tables, and planted her peas and carrots. Now, she is ready to plant her tomatoes and cucumbers, so Aria and Omar have to calculate how much land they need for all their larger vegetables.

Omar is very proud of Aria for memorizing her multiples! Now, they will use those skills in the garden and also memorize more multiples from 6 to 9!

feedback.html: Good job!

No, that's not correct. Make sure your first box has the answer to 3 * 1, your last box has the answer to 3 * 9, and you only have one number in each box (you are pressing "add item" after each number you enter.)

hint_content.html:
In each text box, you should only enter one number.

The first text box should have the answer to 3 * 1. The second text box should have the answer to 3 * 2. The last text box should have the answer to 3 * 9.

content.html:
"Good job, Aria!" said Omar, looking at Aria's progress on the multiples of 2.

"Now, you already know the first five multiples of 3! So, let's enter all the multiples of 3 into this multiplication table!"

"To fill in the third row of the multiplication table, write the multiples from 3 * 6 to 3 * 9 in order. Separate them with commas. Don't include any spaces! (Ex. a,b,c,d,e)"

feedback.html: Good job!

No, that's not correct. Make sure your first box has the answer to 4 * 1, your last box has the answer to 4 * 9, and you only have one number in each box (you are pressing "add item" after each number you enter.)

hint_content.html:
In each text box, you should only enter one number.

The first text box should have the answer to 4 * 1. The second text box should have the answer to 4 * 2. The last text box should have the answer to 4 * 9.

content.html:
"Great work!" exclaimed Omar.

"Now, let's do the same thing for our multiples of 4."

"To fill in the fourth row of the multiplication table, write the multiples from 4 * 6 to 4 * 9 in order. Separate them with commas. Don't include any spaces! (Ex. a,b,c,d,e)"

feedback.html: Good job!

No, that's not correct. Make sure your first box has the answer to 5 * 1, your last box has the answer to 5 * 9, and you only have one number in each box (you are pressing "add item" after each number you enter.)

hint_content.html:
In each text box, you should only enter one number.

The first text box should have the answer to 5 * 1. The second text box should have the answer to 5 * 2. The last text box should have the answer to 5 * 9.

content.html:
"Good!" said Omar. 

"Now, write the multiples of 5!"

"To fill in the fifth row of the multiplication table, write the multiples from 5 * 6 to 5 * 9 in order. Separate them with commas. Don't include any spaces! (Ex. a,b,c,d,e)"

feedback.html: Good job!

No, that's not correct. Make sure your first box has the answer to 6 * 1, your last box has the answer to 6 * 9, and you only have one number in each box (you are pressing "add item" after each number you enter.)

hint_content.html:
In each text box, you should only enter one number.

The first text box should have the answer to 6 * 1. The second text box should have the answer to 6 * 2. The last text box should have the answer to 6 * 9.

content.html:
"You're making some amazing progress!" said Omar. "Keep it up! Let's continue to fill the table, one row at a time. Now, we'll work on our multiples of 6!"

"To fill in the sixth row of the multiplication table, write the multiples from 6 * 6 to 6 * 9 in order. Separate them with commas. Don't include any spaces! (Ex. a,b,c,d,e)"

feedback.html: Good job!

No, that's not correct. Make sure your first box has the answer to 7 * 1, your last box has the answer to 7 * 9, and you only have one number in each box (you are pressing "add item" after each number you enter.)

hint_content.html:
In each text box, you should only enter one number.

The first text box should have the answer to 7 * 1. The second text box should have the answer to 7 * 2. The last text box should have the answer to 7 * 9.

content.html:
"You're almost there!" said Omar. "Just 7, 8, and 9 left. Now, let's add the multiples of 7 to this table!"

"To fill in the seventh row of the multiplication table, write the multiples from 7 * 6 to 7 * 9 in order. Separate them with commas. Don't include any spaces! (Ex. a,b,c,d,e)"

"You're doing really well, Aria! You're a natural!" Omar said. Aria was very happy.

"These next few days, you should memorize these multiples, so you can start doing them faster, without looking at the table!"

Memorize your multiples from 1 * 1 to 9 * 9. Then, do the next lesson!

feedback.html: Good job! :)
No, that's not right. Use a hint if you need to, and try again!

hint_content.html: The 9th multiple of 2 is another way of asking what 9 * 2 is.
Evaluate 9 * 2 using a picture or addition expression.

content.html:
“Here is the multiplication table so far. We are almost done with the multiples of 2! Let’s finish this,” said Omar.

"What is the 9th multiple of 2? In other words, what is 2 * 9?"

feedback.html: Yes, wonderful job!
No, that's not correct. Remember that the 8th multiple of 2 is the same thing as the product of 8 * 2. Use an addition expression or a picture to help you, and try again!

content.html:
“Excellent! You just filled in the 7 * 2 and the 2 * 7 boxes, which are both 14!" says Omar. "This is what our table looks like so far. Let's keep filling it in!"

"What is the 8th multiple of 2? In other words, what is 8 * 2?"

Aria and her father were finally done planning, planting, and watering their melons, strawberries, peas, carrots, tomatoes, and cucumbers! 

In this exploration, you and Aria learned about:

  • Multiples from 1 * 1 to 9 * 9

Once you have the multiplication table completely memorized, come back next time to help Aria and Omar harvest a vegetable garden to learn more about multiplication!

feedback.html: Correct, well done!
Almost! You found the amount of water Aria needs for 6 tomato plants. How much would you need for six tomato plants and one cucumber plant if each plant needs 6 liters of water? Try again!
Almost! You found the amount of water Aria needs for 1 cucumber plant. How much would you need for 1 cucumber plant and six tomato plants if each plant needs 6 liters of water? Try again!

No, that's not correct. Write a multiplication expression first, and then solve it. If you are having difficulty solving it, go back to your Multiplication table and work harder at memorizing your multiples! Then, try again!

content.html:
“Perfect!” praised Omar. “We need 72 square centimeters to plant one cucumber plant.”

"Now, Aria," said Omar. "Remember that we also need to water all our seeds when we plant them! We are planting seven plants: six tomatoes and one cucumber. Each plant needs 6 liters of water every day."

"How many liters of water do we need every day to water all the tomatoes and cucumbers?"

feedback.html: Correct!

No, that's not correct. Write a multiplication expression first, and then solve it. If you are having difficulty solving it, go back to your Multiplication table and work harder at memorizing your multiples! Then, try again!

hint_content.html: Use the picture to write a multiplication expression, and solve.

content.html:
“Great work!” said Omar. Now that Aria and Omar knew they needed 48 square centimeters for six tomato plants, they were ready to move on to their cucumbers.

Aria looked at the cucumber seed packet. “Each cucumber plant needs a space 8 centimeters wide and 9 centimeters long. But, it doesn’t say the total area of land we need for a cucumber plant.”

“Can you figure that out with what you learned about evaluating multiplication expressions?” asked Omar. "How many square centimeters of land do we need to plant a cucumber plant, if each plant needs an area 8 centimeters wide and 9 centimeters long, as shown in the picture?"

"Good work!” said Omar. “Now that we have added all our multiples of 2 from 2 * 1 to 2 * 9 to our multiplication table, we will start adding other numbers' multiples too!"

"Remember, to fill out a box in the multiplication table, we first write a multiplication expression using the number the box is next to and the number the box is under."

"The number the box is next to is the first factor, and the number the box is under is the second factor."

"For example, for 2 * 6 here, I have circled the 2 on the side, because it is the first factor, and the 6 on the top, because it is the second factor. Finally, we multiply the first and second factor and write their product inside the box. 2 * 6 = 12."

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not correct. The box Omar is pointing to is in the red 7 column and in the blue 2 row. What multiplication expression is this? Use a hint if you need help, and try again!

hint_content.html: Because this box is in the red 7 column and the blue 2 row, the first factor is 7 and the second factor is 2. Write and solve this multiplication expression to find the number in the box.
The multiplication expression is 7 * 2. Use an addition expression or a picture to help you evaluate this.

content.html:
"Good job" said Omar. "Now, Aria, why did we write a 12 in the 2 * 6 and the 6 * 2 boxes?"

"Hmm..." said Aria. "Oh! Because 2 * 6 and 6 * 2 have the same product, we can write 12 in both the 2 * 6 and the 6 * 2 boxes!"

"Right!" said Omar. "Now, what number goes into the box I am pointing to here?"

feedback.html: Correct!
6 * 2 gives us the correct answer, but this box is the 2 * 6 square because 2 is the side number and 6 is the number on the top. Continue to the next card.
No, that's not correct. If you need to, go back to the last lesson to learn how to read a multiplication table. Then, use a hint if you need to, and try again!

hint_content.html: Which red number is Omar's box underneath? This is your first factor. Which blue number is Omar's box next to? This is your second factor.
The box Omar is pointing to is in the 6 column and the 2 row. Remember what you learned about how to read a multiplication table, or go back and relearn. Then, try again!

content.html:
“Here is our multiplication table so far,” said Omar. “You already know all the multiples from 1 * 1 to 1 * 5. Now, let’s see if you can take that further! I already finished the multiples of 1 for you."

"Now, we will fill out this entire table, starting with multiples of 2. First, what is the multiplication expression can we use to find the number that goes into the box I am pointing to?"

feedback.html: Yes, that's right!
No, that's not correct. Spend some more time on memorizing your multiples and try again!

hint_content.html: The multiplication expression for this problem is 7 * 9.

content.html:
"Here's one last question that I need your help with!" said Omar. "In order to grow these larger plants, we need to put some fertilizer in the soil!"

"If I have seven small bags of fertilizer, and each bag has nine cups of fertilizer, how many total cups of fertilizer are in the seven bags?"

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not correct. Spend some more time on memorizing your multiples and try again!

content.html:
“Awesome job!” said Omar. "We know that we have 64 tomato seeds, thanks to you! Now, let's try to see how many cucumber seeds we have."

"I'm ready!" exclaimed Aria. "Bring it on!"

"We have six packets, and each packet has nine cucumber seeds," said Omar. "How many total cucumber seeds do we have?"

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not right. Use addition expressions if it helps. Remember that 3 * 6 is the same thing as adding 3 to itself 6 times. Try again!

content.html:
"Hmm...why do we even need to know our multiples other than gardening, Dad?" asked Aria.

Omar smiled. "Multiplication is useful for a lot of things in life. For example, Aria, you have six older brothers! Next week, I need to buy 3 pencils for each of them because they have to take a big test. So, I need to do 3 * 6 to find the total number of pencils!"

"Oh! So, if I memorize all my multiples, I'll already know what 3 * 6 is right away without adding 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3, so it'll take me less time to solve that problem!" exclaimed Aria.

"Yes! said Omar. "Now, what is 3 * 6 anyway? I need to buy those pencils today!"

feedback.html: Yes, you chose the correct answer!

No, that's not correct. If Aria wants to plant 6 tomato plants, and each plant needs 8 square centimeters each, can you write a multiplication expression for that situation? And when you write it, can you solve it?

content.html:
"I'm so proud of you today, Aria!" said Omar. "It is great how much you learned!" 

Now, it was time for the real fun: getting ready to plant the cucumbers and tomatoes!

“Since we love tomato soup, I think we should plant six plants!" Omar replied.

Aria studied the seed packets. “Each tomato seedling needs a minimum of 8 square centimeters,” she read. "If one tomato plant needs 8 square centimeters of land, how many square centimeters do we need to plant six tomato plants?"

feedback.html: Good job!
That's not right. Try again. Remember, the first number in the multiplication expression is the number on the side of the table, and the second number is the number on top!

content.html:
"Congratulations on completing the table!" Omar exclaimed.

"It was a lot of work, but I did it!" said Aria.

"I'm trying to figure out how many tomato seeds there are in all these packets!" said Omar, thinking.

"We can use multiplication!" said Aria, excitedly.

"Oh? Yes!" said Omar. "There's eight packets and eight seeds in each packet. How many total seeds are there? Try using the multiplication table you just made!"

feedback.html: Good job! Correct.
No, that's not right. Go back to the last lesson and memorize your multiples from 1 * 1 to 5 * 5. Come back, and try again!

content.html: "Great!" said Omar. "Now, what is 3 * 3?"

feedback.html: Correct!
Remember that only addition expressions have addends and sums. Try again!
Incorrect. A product is the answer to a multiplication expression. Try again.
No, that's not right. Go back to Lesson 1 and learn what factors and products are. Then, try again!

content.html:
"Okay Aria, get ready!" said Omar. "Before we move on though, let’s make sure that you remember the things we discussed last time!"

"In 8 * 9 = 72, what do we call 9?"

exploration.title: Single Digit Expressions from 5 to 9
exploration.objective: In this story, you and Aria will continue learning about single-digit multiplication expressions.
